title: letters to the editor march 27 2020
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Like so many residents of Islay and Jura I was shocked to read that the Daily Mail has published an article siting areas that are the #best boltholes# for escape from the Corona virus. Included in this is the Isle of Jura.This is as shockingly reckless as it is offensive.The Isle of Jura is not a #bolthole# as the Daily Mail has chosen to state but a very beautul island steeped in culture and rich history.On both Jura and Islay we, like so many rural areas, are struggling to deal with all of the challenges related to the Corona virus out break. Our local health services have very limited resources as it is, along side a population that has many elderly residents who are more at risk to the virus.We have seen a local uptick in people traveling to Islay in camper vans and this is happening at a time when the UK government is advising against non essential travel.Those who are choosing to travel to our islands of Islay, Jura and the many other islands in Argyll and Bute in order to avoid the coronavirus may end up inadvertently spreading it to islands who arenot as much affected in the same way as so many built up urban areas are. Such actions are as reckless as they are selfish and I would implore people who do not need to travel to our rural constituency to avoid doing so until this global pandemic has passed.Jura, Islay and the rest of Argyll are some of the most beautul places you will ever visit and you won#t find an area where the people are more hospitable and friendly but while this crisis is ongoing I would ask everyone who is not currently living here to avoid traveling here for the time being.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands ward.To the Scottish public,During this time of unprecedented uncertainty, we are all concerned about the safety and wellbeing of our families, friends and colleagues.Our hearts go out to those who have been affected personally by the outbreak of coronavirus , as well as the many communities around the world that are facing extreme measures in an attempt to slow its spread.We appreciate and are mindful of the challenges iniduals are currently facing as well as the impact this pandemic has had on our vital emergency services as well as the grocery retail sector, supply chain and producers.Like our retail partners, we want to take this opportunity to assure you that Scottish farmers, auctioneers, hauliers, processors and butchers are doing everything they can to maintain the ongoing availability of fresh, locally sourced Scotch Beef PGI, Scotch Lamb PGI and Specially Selected Pork.We would like to thank all those who work in the Scottish red meat industry and their families for their ongoing and unwavering efforts to keep our supermarket shelves and butcher shops stocked, fuelling Scotland with top-quality red meat during this challenging time.As bodies supporting the Scottish agricultural and red meat industry, we are constantly reviewing the developing situation and are doing all we can to support everyone involved in putting nutritious food on your plates.Alan Clarke, chief executive, Quality Meat ScotlandMartin Morgan, executive manager, Scottish Association of Meat Wholesalers Duncan Todd, secretary, Scottish Beef Association Jen Craig, president, National Sheep Association Scotland Penny Montgomerie, chief executive, Scottish Association of Young Farmers Clubs and Gordon King, executive manager, Scottish Craft Butchers.What on earth is going on  It was banal enough when Ben Goldsmith # English financier and environmentalist # tweeted that #overgrazing# by upland sheep farmers, was responsible for the devastating floods in South Wales, rather than record-breaking torrential rainfall.Unbelievably we now have a government official, Dr Tim Leunig, suggesting the whole of the UK does not need farming, and his comparison of the UK to Singapore in this context is absolutely ludicrous. You truly have to wonderthere is something in the water that he is drinking – could it be flood contamination Surely, every person having a full and ing set of neurons and synapses, the complete opposite is the truth, as we dearly need our hard working farming community.The UK Government should be fully supporting the farming industry and indeed, good land management. The Welsh Assembly has totally lost its way with its mindless policy of devastating Welsh forests with thousands and thousands # an understatement # of trees being felled for wind farms, and compounding the felony by covering acres of land with very limited electricity generating solar parks # Wales is not the Sahara and the sun disappears at night! Solar  will generate about  per cent of their maximum capacity in the UK.Returning to farming perhaps some kind person should tell Dr Tim Leunig that the answer lies in the soil and then lead him to a darkened and quiet room so he can lie down and contemplate the truth # wise men recognise that truth is the daughter of time, not of authority.Dave Haskell, Cardigan.

title: donald clark a tribute
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsDonald Clark was for  years the convivial, larger-than-le host at The George Hotel in Inveraray, a notable bon viveur and one of the most colourful characters in Argyll. He died aged  on January  after a short illness.Latterly, his mobility hampered by a leg injury, he would sit in the corner of The George public bar on an over-sized carved wooden stool. From his throne he dispensed news, advice and anecdotes – albeit not always historically accurate. His inimitable irony, perfectly-timed humour and the occasional reprimand to a wayward customer were all fuelled by a generous glass.As former president of the Scottish Licensed Trade Association and Keeper of the Quaich, Donald knew the intricacies of the business intimately from personal experience. His taste was eclectic and his appetite substantial, extending from Dom Perignon and Saint-Émilion Grand Cru to Tennent’s lager and Glen Dronach single malt. On a hot day he’d have an icy Martini or a gin and tonic, proportionately scaled up in a pint glass. Being askedhe had time for a quick ‘small one’, he would reply: #I’ll decide the size for myself,you don’t mind.#The records suggest that his frequent claim to be Scottish Slimmer of the Year, after getting his weight down from  stone to  stone, was fancul.Big D, as he was often called, was fastidious about standards in the little public bar, training his regulars to clear tables of empty glasses and plates promptly, and to keep the log fire stoked on winter evenings.If one of his regulars turned up untypically well-dressed, Donald would raise an eyebrow in mild surprise:  #What’s the occasion for the suit   A funeral   Your latest marriage   Or has your court case come up #In summer, an erratic stream of foreign tourists would have their first encounter with a Scottish pub, standing in the doorway bewildered as to what happens next – sit or stand  Fight their way to the mobbed bar or go to a table and wait for the non-existent waitress  Donald would call them over to his corner and was soon plying them with drinks, food and conversation, not infrequently paying the entire bill for his astonished guests.When a tourist asked him about the quaint red GPO telephone box in Church Square, he told them: #We have the fastest modern communications here – telephone, teletext and tell Donald.#Donald was a Francophile and loved his summers in Collioure, where #Le Grand Ecossais# was almost as well-known as in Argyll. A fixture of the local bars and restaurants, and frequently crossing the border to patronise Spanish hostelries, he revelled in the region’s seafood, wine and culture.His hobbies included cooking, opera, reading and lively conversation on a sweeping range of topics from local history to civil engineering. His knowledge was genuinely wide, but when occasionally encountering someone with a superior command of the topic in question, he would quickly change the subject and admonish: “Och, you’re showing off now.”Donald Clark was born on  July , in Rotten Row hospital, Glasgow. He was the youngest child of Donald Clark and Elizabeth Inglis, following by nine years his only sibling, Fiona.His early years were spent in Inveraray where family le revolved around his parents’ hotel in the little white-washed town.He was schooled at Inveraray Primary and Larchfield in Helensburgh, then Strathallan from  to  where he acquired his love of sports. Contrary to what his dimensions in later le would suggest, he was athletic when young, excelling at rugby and playing for his school and West of Scotland First XV and the old boys’ As.Donald also enjoyed curling, motor boating, snow skiing and water-skiing, where his party piece was to mono-ski down Loch Fyne while drinking a pint of beer.Although not a shinty player, he used his sports experience to coach the Inveraray team in the s and like his father chaired the club. In , he flamboyantly arrived in Inverness by helicopter for Inveraray#s Camanachd Final against Kingussie.

title: mysterious island monk explored in new book
story: Ellis ButcherUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe prehistoric and medieval landmarks of western Scotland take centre stage in a new book telling the story of one of the greatest northern saints.The Man Who Gave his Horse to a Beggar, by John Connell, follows in the footsteps of Aidan of Lindisfarne, taking the reader on an odyssey through Ireland and northern Britain.The Scotland section features Iona, where the charismatic holy man lived as a monk before embarking on a dangerous journey to preach to the pagan English.The lavishly-illustrated book features photographs from award-winning writer and exhibition designer Phil Cope, and is a biography of a man about whom little is known until now.It takes the reader to the rocky outcrop of Dunadd, seat of the warrior kings of Dál Riata, and explores the ancient monuments of Kilmartin Glen, near  Lochgilphead.Temple Wood Stone Circle and the standing stones of Nether Largie were visible in Aidan’s time too, while Dunadd would have been a thriving cosmopolitan centre.It was in this part of what is now Argyll and Bute that Aidan is thought to have encountered his future lord, St Oswald of Northumbria, an exiled Anglo-Saxon prince living in the court of the Gaelic kings.When he ed to reclaim his rightful kingdom at the point of a sword – a story that inspired JRR Tolkien’s The Lord of the Rings – Oswald invited Aidan to establish a monastery on Lindisfarne basing it on the Iona model.Part-biography and part-pilgrimage, The Man Who Gave his Horse To A Beggar takes the reader back in time but also asks what lessons this neglected holy man might have for our own troubled times.Named in honour of one of Aidan’s most revealing acts, the work explores why Aidan has so often been overlooked and aims to restore him to his rightful place as one of the greatest figures in Irish and British history.Mr Connell, age , a former journalist, said: #Iona was among the most memorable destinations in our epic travels through Britain and Ireland.#We arrived in late March of , before the Easter rush. The beauty and calm of the island made a lasting impression on me.#The monuments of Kilmartin Glen are also at the very heart of the book’s major themes, including kingship and the sacredness of landscape.#And it was at Dunadd that Aidan would have seen the kings of Dál RiataPortals to this other-world still survive, suggested by mountains, forgotten ruins, holy wells and standing stones, crosses and caves, said Mr Connell.Born in Newcastle, he now lives in Cumbria, England, with his partner and their daughter.He previously worked for titles including The Edinburgh Evening News, with bylines in The Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday.The book has been published by Culture and Democracy Press and is available to purchase online through Amazon for £.

story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsBefore coronavirus restrictions were imposed, Argyll Bird Club provided monthly field trip outings around mainland Argyll led by experienced bird watchers.With most bird surveying suspended as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, the club is relieved it has now chosen a species which can be surveyed from home within government advice.Swts are slightly larger than swallows and have an all-dark plumage with a short forked tail. They feed on flying insects and spend most of their le in the air # including when they sleep # usually coming down to earth to breed. They are fast fliers, often chasing one another over buildings when they give a screeching call.Swts arrive back in Argyll in early May and breed in towns, villages and other buildings in Argyll. They spend around three months in Argyll, departing early-mid August to their wintering grounds in Africa.The British Trust for Ornithology’s Breeding Bird Survey indicates the population of Swts in Scotland has declined by around  per cent since . A similar decline has taken place in England and Wales. The reasons for the decline are not fully known but are believed to be related to changes in insect numbers and a lack of nesting sites as buildings are modernised.Argyll is at the north-western limit of the world range of Swts. Their distribution and numbers in Argyll is not well-known and the purpose of the Argyll Bird Club Survey is to try to find out the size of the breeding population and where they remain.If you have a Swt nesting in your building, or near you, or would like to take part in this survey further information is available at http:argyllbirdclub.org argyll-surveysFor more information about Argyll Bird Club, email Jim Dickson at Argyllbirder@outlook.

title: letters to the editor april 24 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,A few weeks ago I launched an appeal on social media aimed at supporting nurses and medics at the Mid Argyll Hospital during this terrible COVID- pandemic.I was initially trying to find outthere was anyone locally who might be interested in dusting down their sewing machine to make a few sets of protective ‘scrubs’ to donate to the hospital. Within a couple of days the response was staggering.There were volunteers from all corners of Mid Argyll willing to sew, donate material and give freely of their time. Local businesses were also quick to respond with offers of material, pattern printing and transport for moving stock around.I am overwhelmed by the support and generosity of people in Mid Argyll. They have risen to the challenge and far exceeded my expectations.We have around  stitchers from Cairndow to Ardfern, and villages and towns in between, producing brightly coloured ‘scrubs’ using mainly donated fabric, scrap material and jazzy duvet covers. The first donation of ‘scrubs’ is expected to be handed over to the hospital this week and we are sure they will brighten up the wards.Our crowdfunding page, ‘Let’s Get Scrubbing for Mid Argyll’, was originally set up to buy everything to make the scrubs. It has broken the original £ target and we would love to hit the £, mark so please feel free to donate.I am overwhelmed and humbled by this experience and publicly thank the group team leaders, the volunteer stitchers, those working behind the scenes and the wider community for their support and generosity.My thanks is also extended to the following businesses who have helped in so many ways: MacLeod Construction, Kit-You-Out, Mary’s Meals, Top Designer, West Coast Motors, LG Upholstery, Clock Tower, Tarbert COS Thrt Shop, Premier Laundry, Ian Y McIntyre, Willie Leitch Sailmaker, Owen Sails and the Lithgow Family at Ormsary Estate.Nikki Thompson, Ardrishaig.Sir,The time will come when we are through the turmoil of this pandemic but as we work our way through it, I wanted to share a situation that reflects the actions of many.I was recently collecting shopping in Tarbert for registered vulnerable people and, as I was taking off my gloves before getting into the car, I was aware of another#s presence close by pushing a mobile rubbish bin. It was Damon. He saw me about to put my gloves into the rubbish bag in my own car and said cheerily #You can pop them into this bin here,you like#.I was so taken by that gesture. What an example of initiative, thoughtfulness and kindness. It summed up the incredible work of so many volunteers, co-ordinated by Team Tarbert#s Fiona, with Margaret co-ordinating prescriptions, and many others.Perhaps there is no better time for us all to reaquaint ourselves with Rudyard Kipling#s poem #If#.It seems to perfectly summarise humanity working at its best, in which, during this crisis, thanks to so many, Tarbert can walk tall. Stay safe.Peter Minshall, Tarbert.Sir,I write regarding the Argyllshire Advertiser edition dated Friday April  and the front page heading #Hospital prepares for Pandemic#.The article states: #No figures have been released about the incidence of coronavirus in Argyll and Bute# because the HSCP spokesperson said #we are following national guidance and due to reasons of patient confidentiality we will not be able to make public where in the Highland health board areas the positive cases are#.This statement is complete nonsense and shows either the HSCP in Argyll has not been privy to this information or they are just using the term #national guidance# as a smokescreen and an excuse and or sheer incompetence.No-one was asking them for patients# names and addresses, merely figures of those affected in a given area.The people appointed to positions of responsibility in Argyll and Bute HSCP are hopeless when it comes to joined-up thinking and accountability.All they will do is spin you a line and quote stuff like #national guidelines#, which is code for #I don#t have a clue#.Karl Edwards, LochgilpheadSir,Scottish and Southern Electricity Networksis extending the support it provides to those most vulnerable by expanding the eligibility of its Priority Services Registerto include customers at increased risk of severe illness during the coronavirus pandemic.Nearly , customers already receive additional care and support through SSEN’s PSR – a free, tailored service.In addition to those self-isolating or shielding for  weeks, customers are eligiblethey:Julie Walker, SSEN.

title: boris stay alert message vague
story: Ellis ButcherUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsBoris Johnson#s plans to drop the public #stay at home# message in place of #stay alert,# has been criticised by Scotland#s First Minister this afternoon.Nicola Sturgeon told a media briefing that she did not know what #stay alert# meant and that it did not apply to Scotland, where #stay at home# remains the advice because of the #fragility# of the coronavirus.She has also asked that a UK Government advertising campaign with the message should not be broadcast in Scotland, it emerged, with public relations teams of both governments in talks over the issue today.It follows reports that UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson will drop stay at home in favour of stay alert in a televised speech tonight.Mrs Sturgeon said it was reasonable for the leaders of the four nations to make decisions based on the evidence in their countries.But she added that a message of stay alert could be confusing to people.She told reporters: #I don#t know what stay alert means. Presumably, we all live our lives, in normal times, staying alert to danger.#If I said to you now that my message is stay alert, and you say to me #does that mean I stay at home or not # I can#t give you a straight answer to that.#Therefore I would be failing in my duty to be clear in terms of what I am asking you to do.#That#s why stay at home is important in Scotland right now and it#s why I am going to continue for as long, but not any longer, than I think it is necessary, to ask you to follow that advice.#It appears Mr Johnson failed to properly consult with other leaders of the Home Nations.Mrs Sturgeon suggested she had been left to read about the change of tack in a national newspaper, which she called not #helpful or sensible#.Information about what people could, or could not do, was #critical# to their safety, she added, saying it was an issue of #le and death#, not politics.#For Scotland right now, given the fragility of the progress we have made, given the critical point that we are at would be catastrophic for me to drop the stay at home message, that#s why I am not prepared to do it,# she said.Of Mr Johnson, she added: #He has to be clear with people that some of what he is saying applies to England, not to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.#There will be other things that he says, around border control for example, that applies for the whole of the UK. There#s a responsibility on all of us to be clear in our messaging and the applicability of that messaging.#She said it was dficultdecisions were being taken which, even #inadvertently# were presented as #UK wide when they are not#.Meanwhile, the Scottish Government has decided to drop the #once-a-day# exercise restriction.

The bikes are from the project’s new e-bike loan scheme, a partnership with Mid Argyll Community Pool, which was ready to be launched when lockdown measures were introduced.The free bike loans have gone out to key workers including a nurse, pharmacy staff, a teacher, a supermarket worker and a GP surgery practice manager. Many participants also received a helmet, lock and a puncture repair kit to help keep them on the road.Alec Ohnstad, project co-ordinator for the Ardrishaig Bothy, said: #We’re delighted our e-bikes are being put to good use by key workers and others who will benefit from them.#Many people are using cycling to get from A to B during the lockdown, while others are finding it’s a real boost to their health and well-being. When social distancing guidelines are relaxed we look forward to launching our e-bike library, but in the meantime we can’t think of a better use for the bikes.#Cycling journeys in Scotland have shot up during lockdown, with recent figures released by Transport Scotland showing a  per cent increase compared to typical levels.Cycling UK is also providing free essential cycling services and repairs for key workers through the Big Bike Revival for key workers scheme.The charity is working with more than  independent bike shops, recycling centres and mechanics workshops in Scotland – including Fyne Bike Cycle Repair in Ardrishaig. title: gamers-enjoy-e-sports-success-gala-fairydean-rovers
story: A TEAM of online gamers are representing Gala Fairydean Rovers FC in a virtual football competition.Gas engineer Darren Smith, of Galashiels, helped launch an -a-side league on FIFA  in which his hometown club has been enjoying considerable success.Smith, , told the Border : ldquoConsidering itrsquos the first season, itrsquos been excellent ndash and so has the reaction wersquove got from people.The Scottish league, played on a PlayStation , contains a number of teams representing official clubs, including Berwick Rangers, Greenock Morton andEast Stirlingshire.But the Galashiels side has been performing admirably, according to Smith ndash who has his sights set on a lofty finish.ldquoWersquove only beaten twice, said Smith, whose side currently sit third. ldquoLast Sunday we got beaten and we got beaten on the first day of the season.He added: ldquoWersquore still to play the second-placed team and wersquore still to play the team at the top.ldquoI thinkwe go unbeaten and they drop a few points, itrsquos there to be done and Irsquod be happy with second place.A total of  players have signed up to Galarsquos virtual squad, with three players from the town itself.As the recruitment drive was mainly carried out through Twitter, Smith was able to procure the services of gamers from across Britain and further afield. One of the goalkeepers, for instance, lives in Egypt.Asked to describe what it is like playing a video game in co-operation with  other people, Smith indicated it has been a hugely enjoyable experience.He said: ldquoPlaying with  others is sometimes challenging when it comes to getting everyone on for a certain time.ldquoHowever, being manager of the team, I have the luxury of picking who is in the team and I have managed to get some really good guys in who are competitive but also able to enjoy playing the game, which is what its all about in the end.When the real-le football season is in full swing, Smith takes to the park for Lauder Amateur FC.But, for now, the left-back is quite happy plying his trade for Gala online - and he is already considering adding a second tier to the virtual set-up next season.ldquoThe competition gives people a place to go and relax and enjoy themselves without the stresses of les problems, he said.

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. title: mays-super-flower-moon-see-uk
story: A so-called lsquoFlower Moonrsquo will be spotted over the skies of the UK this week.Not only that, but Mays full moon will also be a supermoon, making it a Super Flower Moon.But just what does all that mean What is a Flower Moon The May full moon is traditionally known as the Flower Moon simply because it appears at the time of blossoming flowers.What is a supermoon The moon - our planets only natural satellite - actually follows an elliptical orbit around the Earth.This means that at certain points on its egg-shaped path, it can be further away, or closer to us - a dferential of about , miles.The closest point is called the perigee, and the furthest is the apogee. When a full moon falls on the perigee, it appears far bigger and brighter in the sky and becomes known as a supermoon.The phenomenon is not actually that rare, and this months is last in a trilogy that began with Marchs full moon..During a supermoon,the diameter of the moon canappear to be about  per cent greater than an average full moon.What timewill the moon be biggest The full moon will be in the night sky on the evening of Thursday, May , though it will technically be at its fullest at :am on Thursday morning.Seeing as it wont even be in the sky then - let alone visible in daylight - the fullest youll get to see the moon will come at around .pm on Thurday, when the moon rises.It will be in the sky all night, and wont set again until about .am the following morning, offering plenty of time for you to catch a glimpse.For the best effect ndash and the closest yoursquoll get to witnessing the spectacular images seen across social media following such an event ndash yoursquoll want to look east shortly after moonrise.ldquoWhen the moon is near the horizon, it can look unnaturally large when viewed through trees, buildings, or other foreground objects," say NASA."The effect is an optical illusion, but that fact doesnrsquot take away from the experience."What  should I look out for This months full moon ties in nicely with the peak of the Eta Aquariids meteor shower.The meteor shower has been going on above our heads for a couple of weeks, and runs roughly from April  - May .However, it is this week when budding astronomers are likely to get the best show, as the shower peaks on the night of May  into May .The Eta Aquariids should be visible with the naked eye, although the glare from a full supermoon will make them harder to spot.Those living in built up areas would usually be advised to travel to less populated spaces and to avoid light pollutionthey really want to see the shower, but with ongoing lockdown restrictions and the coronavirus pandemic, that is not advised.Wrapping up in warm clothes is recommended, and you should allow up to  minutes for your eyes to fully adjust to the night sky.The Eta Aquariids are not one of the years most spectacular meteor showers, and usually peak at around  meteors per hours - thats just under one a minute.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: 65th-anniversary-couple-met-galashiels-academy

title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

title: historic-borders-house-needs-20k-planned-re-opening
story: A STATELY home in the Borders needs pound, so it can re-open to the public in the summer, according to trustees.Paxton House, in Berwickshire, has been closed since the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown in March.But now the Paxton Trust is urging the public to donate by June  so the th century estate can open its doors again in July.Trust chairman Ian Marrian said: ldquoWe want to re-open as soon as itrsquos safe for all and wersquoll have to invest to ensure that safety."We cannot compromise on the conservation of our nationally signicant collections and the glorious natural landscape."But every day without income makes survival a greater challenge."Mr Marrian said the trust is also working "extremely hard" to try to gain a grant to cover the essential running costs for .He added: "We hope that,and when we re-open, we can with your help and attendance make these strange times a little happier.The trust, which has earmarked July  for re-opening, says it needs pound, by the start of the summer to maintain the property, as well as the childrenrsquos playground and gardens.The house was gted to the nation in  by John David Home Robertson, the last laird, for the populations "benefit and enjoyment".Its collection of paintings includes work by Allan Ramsay, Sir Henry Raeburn and Alexander Nasmyth.The house also boasts Scotlands largest collection of Thomas Chippendale furniture.

title: selkirk-firms-help-make-25-000-face-shields
story: TWO Selkirk companies have combined to help make more than , face shields for hospitals and local businesses.Cademuir Engineering and Eadie Bros and Co have worked together since the start of April to supply D-printed visors, of which , have been sent to Selkirk-based workwear distributor Guthrie Group.The Guthrie Groups Selkirk manager Alan Skeldon said: ldquoIts great to have local businesses with the ability to make face shields, allowing us to supply to local healthcare facilities.A club of engineering enthusiasts based in Edinburgh, called Edinburgh Shield Force, contacted Eadie Bros for help making personal protective equipmentfor frontline workers.The engineers needed headbands for the face shields they were distributing to Scottish healthcare workers, including those at the Borders General Hospital.Using Eadie Brosrsquo injection-moulding tool, Cademuir made the headbands using state-of-the art equipment which enables each part to be robotically handled, minimising contamination risk and increasing the production rate to , a day.Cademuir Engineering production manager Marc Phaup said: ldquoIts fantastic to be involved in this important project for our NHS, along with supplying local businesses like Guthrie Group.ldquoThere are a lot of dferent groups who have come together to achieve the goal of getting PPE to our frontline workers.A spokesperson for the Edinburgh Shield Force added: ldquoThis project has only been possible because of the combined experience of our team, the tireless dedication of our volunteers and the flexibility and hard work of our partners Eadie Bros and Co and Cademuir Engineering.Edinburgh Shield Force is relying on a fundraising appeal, which you can access through this link.

title: man-shows-off-160-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A BORDERS man has come forward with a -year-old copy of a local newspaper.Mitchell Johnston, of Peebles, spotted last weekrsquos articlein the Peeblesshire Newsdocumenting council leader Shona Haslamrsquos surprise discovery while renovating her new house.Mrs Haslam unearthed an edition of the Peebles Newsdated February , , when tidying up the old courthouse at Peebles High Street.But now Mr Johnston, , wishes to showcase one of his own prized possessions ndash a copy of the Peeblesshire Advertiserfrom December , .Mr Johnston, a retired member of the merchant navy, said the paper had originally belonged to his uncle John Somerville, who emigrated to Canada in about  and became the manager of a mill.Mr Johnston said Somerville, born in , died in . title: 100th-staging-agricultural-show-postponed
story: FARMERS will have to wait until next year for the th staging of a Borders agricultural show.Organisers of Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society Show have taken the decision to cancel the  edition.The societys secretary Alison Renwick said the committee "felt duty-bound" to call off the showpiece.She added: ldquoThis yearrsquos show would have been particularly memorable, as committee members had already started working on a number of special projects to commemorate the th staging.ldquoThese plans will, of course, now be carried over to the  event and Irsquom very confident next yearrsquos show will prove every bit as successful as this yearrsquos would have been.Although the first show staged by the Yarrow  Ettrick Pastoral Society took place in September, , the societyrsquos origins stretch back  years prior to that with the formation of the Selkirk Farmer Club .The new societyrsquos formation came after a public meeting was held in the Gordon Arms in May, , to "consider the desirability of forming a society for the purpose of organising an annual show of sheep and cattle".Descendants of farmers present at that inaugural meeting continue to live and work in the Yarrow and Ettrick Valleys, thereby helping to keep alive the traditions and high standards which have become the hallmark of the societyrsquos past  shows.The organisers added: "We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved with Yarrow Show, including all volunteers, sponsors, traders, exhibitors and public, whose support is essential to the future of the show."The society looks forward to welcoming you back next year."

title: borders-college-students-deliver-medicine-vulnerable-folk
story: BORDERS College students are delivering medicine to vulnerable peoplersquos homes during lockdown.A total of  students and staff have given up their time to drop off more than  prescriptions across the region.The colleges work placement co-ordinator Verity Hislop said: "The students are quite happy to do it ndash they enjoy it."The college is working with NHS Borders and Scottish Borders Council to run the scheme, which is being led by Ms Hislop.She said: ldquoAlthough wersquove no direct contact with the iniduals wersquore delivering to, we get a wave or a smile or a thank you from a distance."And we certainly know they are appreciative, from the expression on their face."If we didnrsquot deliver, they wouldnrsquot be able to get their medicines.ldquoThese are iniduals who fall into the vulnerable group ndash theyrsquove been told by the NHS they need to isolate.ldquoThere was a huge demand on pharmacies and a lot of iniduals in ious communities fall into the vulnerable category."We sent out a call to staff and students ndash but only those who are PVGscheme members."All the Borders staff fall under that, and also the health and social care students."Originally, pharmacies notied the NHS Borders Transport Hub about prescriptions that needed to be picked up.But now pharmacies are contacting the Borders College delivery team directly with their requests.ldquoThe Transport Hub emailed me with requests for prescription pick-ups from the pharmacy, said Ms Hislop, ldquoand then I would arrange for volunteers to go to the pharmacies, pick up the prescription and deliver them to the people who needed them.ldquoBut now wersquore getting phone calls directly from the pharmacies, with the increase in demand.She added: ldquoBorders College sees its role as supporting our community and during these unprecedented times there is a desire to contribute and add value by volunteering.ldquoThe college is exceptionally proud and grateful to everyone who is involved. This collaborative mission helps to protect vulnerable groups within the community and potentially saves lives.ldquoA huge thank you to all the volunteers, NHS Borders and NHS Transport Hub.

story: GALASHIELS rugby players have raised more than pound, for the local foodbank ndash and delivered carloads of supplies.Over two successive weekends, Gala RFC invited supporters to drop off food at the gates of Scott Park.Gala president Ian Dalgleish said: ldquoEveryonersquos generosity was fantastic.The weekend of April - saw nearly pound left by players, committee members, supporters and the general public ndash in addition to bags of groceries.The second weekend of collections, on May , raised pound ndash including a bottle of coins totalling pound from residents at Abbotsford Court.Mr Dalgleish said: ldquo[Captain] Euan Dods and [vice captain] Rex Jeffrey and other volunteers were collecting the food and donations at Scott Park, and then the bags were delivered to St Peterrsquos Church for the foodbank.ldquoThe bottle of coins donated by the folk at Abbotsford Court was pound ndash they donrsquot have a lot of money to give out but when they found out there was pound in the bottle they actually topped it up to pound.Galashiels Foodbank co-ordinator John Tucker said: ldquoWe are really thrilled to have all this local support.ldquoNearly pound, was raised in two weekends, and Herculean amounts of food ndash two carloads of food both weekends ndash so our stocks are right up to where we want them to be, which is wonderful.ldquoIn times of hardship people are thinking of each other. The public have really got their support behind this initiative and they just came along with food and money.ldquoBefore COVID, we were giving out maybe  carrier bags of food a week."At [the viruss peak] about two weeks ago we gave out  ndash a fourfold increase in demand.And the foodbank is not the only local charity to benefit from the generosity of the rugby club players.Gala Menrsquos Shed, whose members are making face visors for care workers, was the grateful recipient of a pound donation by the rugby club.Scottish Borders Menrsquos Shed developer Ross Hall described the donation as "fantastic".He said: "It took us over a wee setback in terms of supply, and Gala stepped in at just the right time to help us make more visors."So we had a wee break due to funding and now wersquore back on track. title: aussie-rugby-player-caring-galashiels-lockdown
story: A KIND-HEARTED Australian rugby player has been delivering food to elderly folk in the Borders town he currently calls home.Gala RFC forward Cody Roman, , moved from Wollongong, New South Wales, in October last year.When coronavirus put paid to his plans to explore more of the Borders, he decided to channel his free time into volunteering as a driver with Food Train.He said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate that Irsquom mobile so I want to get out and help those who are less fortunate or in need."For six weeks, Cody has been dropping off food to residents who are self-isolating.He said: ldquoIt got to the end of winter and I was looking forward to seeing some nice summer days, and then this [lockdown] happened.ldquoThe club put a post on social media askingthere were any guys ready to help out with anything, like shopping or dog-walking or anything that people were unable to do now, for people who had to self-isolate.ldquoThe Food Train commented on the post, and I was like, lsquoIrsquoll do itrsquo. And Irsquove being doing it for six weeks now.ldquoItrsquos been really good ndash everyone appreciates it. Some people who live alone might not have seen anyone for a few days, so theyrsquore very happy when we come out to them and have a chat.ldquoSome of them are very excited and grateful. Some of them offer us a cup of tea and we have to let them down easy."Despite being so far from his home Down Under, Cody is coping well with the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoItrsquos not too bad, with Facebook and social media and stuff. I can just send messages and give people a call."And Irsquom pretty fortunate where I live ndash everyonersquos very friendly.

title: ex-lauder-footballer-toasts-50th-anniversary-cup-win
story: A REUNION to mark the th anniversary of Lauder Amateur FC clinching the South of Scotland Cup has been cancelled due to coronavirus.Lauder triumphed - over Tweeddale Rovers at Netherdale, Galashiels, on May , .Members of the successful side had been planning to meet up this summer, but COVID- has put paid to the proposal.George Threadgall, , told the Border that he still treasures memories of Lauderrsquos achievement.ldquoIt was like the European Cup for us, said the former defender, adding: ldquoI think half of Lauder was there that night.Led by coaches Jim Brotherston and Alex McDonald, Lauder went down - through an own goal, recalled Mr Threadgall, before roaring back to put their noses in front.After Rovers hoofed a penalty kick over the bar in the dying minutes, Mr Threadgall and team-mates celebrated a famous victory when they arrived home.ldquoYou go to Lauder and mention the South team and locals will bore you to tears about how big a thing it was for the town, said Mr Threadgall, a retired engineer living in Linlithgow.Lauderrsquos goals came courtesy of forwards Jimmy Gillie and Stan Seaton, said Mr Threadgall, with centre-half Kenny Rutherford being the unfortunate player who turned the ball into his own net.The reunion had been planned for late July or early August in Lauderrsquos Golden Bannock pub, said Mr Threadgall.Guests would have included Dave Elrick, now living in South Africa, who was Lauder Cornet in the year he helped his hometown side to the cup.Mr Threadgall, a grandfather, was himself Lauder Cornet in .

title: furlough-extension-mean-workers-businesses
story: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has announced that the Governmentrsquos furlough scheme is to be extended until the end of October. But what does it all mean for workers and businesses  The PA news agency takes a look.ndash What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive % of their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.ndash Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.ndash Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the % mark.The job retention scheme will be extended, for four months, until the end of October.By that point, we will have provided eight months of support to British people and businesses. Until the end of July, there will be no changes to the scheme whatsoever. pic gQznYcIrmdash Rishi SunakMay , ndash How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.ndash Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.ndash Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.ndash Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Furlough extension: What does it mean for workers and businesses

title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans
story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the school roll, which is currently , including the nursery.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoWe have submitted a planning application to alter and extend St Gabrielrsquos Primary School in Prestonpans.ldquoThe proposed work includes alterations to the nursery, increasing its space by expanding into the existing primary one classroom.ldquoAn extension will create space for a new primary one classroom and provide an additional classroom.ldquoOur five-year capital programme has allocated pound.m for the works, which are required to accommodate an increase in nursery provision through the Scottish Governmentrsquos expansion of funded early learning and childcare, as well as the need for additional classroom space.ldquoIn addition, the classroom extension will receive developersrsquo contributions from Blindwells and the nursery expansion will receive funding from the Scottish Government.Plans showing the proposed changes are now with the local authorityrsquos planning department.The school, which has been extended several times over the years, first opened its doors in .Currently, it has seven open plan classrooms, with two further nursery playrooms and other facilities.The proposed works would see two new primary school classrooms, as well as an expanded nursery space with new external canopy and the existing nursery reconfigured.The design and access statement included within the planning application notes: ldquoThe completed extension will provide state-of-the-art teaching and play facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief, as well as promoting energy efficiency through its design.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The plans for the school could ultimately be decided by the local authorityrsquos planning committee, with all four members of the Preston Seton Gosford ward ndash Lachlan Bruce, Neil Gilbert, Willie Innes and Fiona OrsquoDonnell ndash part of the committee.

title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: volunteers-dishing-hundreds-hot-meals
story: The centre is working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council on the initiative, with staff at the centre cooking the meals.More than  volunteers at the local resilience group are helping with packing and deliveries.As many as  families are receiving hot meals or food donations, with deliveries made every day. title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave
story: Ian Millar has been recovering from heart bypass surgery at his home in Haddington and, under lockdown guidelines, has been staying in.However, daughter Susan was determined to make sure his landmark birthday did not go unmarked, and decorated his car with balloons and a poster asking passers-by to wave to her dad.And, last Friday, lots of families out for their daily walk stopped to do just that.Susan said: ldquoDad has not been able to get out of the house and is recovering from his operation so I wanted to surprise him. Lots of people waved to him through his window during the day and he really enjoyed it.Ian, who is originally from Linlithgow, moved to East Lothian with his we Jean more than  years ago, living in Auldhame and Seaclf before settling in North Berwick.A mechanic, Ian worked at Fowlerrsquos Garage and the Bass Rock Garage in the town, before starting East Lothian School of Motoring in .The couple had two children and, following the loss of Jean in  and retirement a year later, Ian moved to Haddington to be closer to daughter Susan.For his th birthday, Susan decorated the car in his driveway on Dobsonrsquos Walk, since they were unable to hold a party.Susan said: ldquoWe put a sign on his car saying, lsquoPlease give me a wave as Irsquom  today,rsquo and dad then spent the day being waved to by passers-by. He even had a visit from the police after a family member in the police in Edinburgh asked local officers to come around! title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. title: nisa-store-steps-donates-1-300-charities-vulnerable
story: Pinkie Farm Convenience Store, one of Nisarsquos independent outlets, has donated essentials to the vulnerable and families in the area who are struggling with financial hardship.Support from the store ndash led by managing director Dan Brown ndash has included a pound donation to East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes, pound to Resilient Musselburgh and a further pound to Pennypit Community Development Trust.East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes provide fresh produce boxes containing all the ingredients needed to prepare a full roast dinner to struggling families.The charityrsquos founder, Jane Russell, said the donation would provide  local families with their dinner boxes.She commented: ldquoI set up the project in December  to give out free fresh chicken dinner boxes to people financially struggling in East Lothian.ldquoThe idea was to create a box of fresh produce so they had everything to cook a Sunday roast chicken dinner, and so the families could all sit together and enjoy a healthy meal.ldquoWe have helped over  families so far. The reason I set it up was because I myself have been in that position and, with three kids, financially struggling is so hard, decidingyou can afford food or gas.ldquoI wanted to make our project easy for people to ask for help without any forms to fill in or feel embarrassed.ldquoThe feedback and the support from the local community to help us is just amazing. The donation we received from Nisa will provide  families with our fresh chicken dinner boxes, which is just amazing.The donations were made via Nisarsquos lsquoMaking a Dference Locallyrsquo charity which raises funds in-store from the sale of Co-op and Heritage own brand products and has seen the Pinkie Farm Convenience Store donate almost pound, to local causes.The donations are just one of many ways in which the store is reaching out to support the local community, having recently launched new pound lsquoessentials kitsrsquo aimed at helping the most vulnerable people in the community and those who are self-isolating.Food kits have also been given to staff at Musselburgh Primary Health Care Centre and fresh produce contributed to East Lothian Foodbank, amongst other initiatives to help those most in need.Thank you for reading this story. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community, reads the nine-page document.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it from the adjacent derelict hall owned by the council.Now, the bowling club, which has about  members, is keen to see improvements carried out, with funding being sought to cover the cost of the scheme which has still to be calculated.A new metal roof could be put in place, with consideration being given to it blending in to the historic surroundings adjacent to Dirleton Castle.Two windows are proposed for the south side of the building to improve the lighting in the clubhouse, while three semi-mature trees could be removed. The trees, according to the design and access statement, cause a number of issues, including not letting light into the building, while their removal would also prevent damage to its foundations caused by the roots.Access to the clubhouse would also be improved through the resurfacing of a footpath, while a new lamppost would be erected to further improve the lighting.Thank you for reading this story. title: queens-maundy-money-sent-church-elders-post
story: Alan Miller and Margaret Jeffrey had been due to travel to St Georgersquos Chapel, Windsor, to attend the Royal Maundy Thursday Service.The annual ceremony sees Queen Elizabeth II present symbolic money to people who have supported their church and community but the event was sadly cancelled due to the global pandemic.Instead, Alan and Margaret, who were both delighted to be given the honour, received the purses in the post.Both of the recipients, who live in East Linton, were shocked to receive letters last year inviting them to the event.Alan told the Courier he was overwhelmed when the letter came in the post and said: ldquoThe first thing I thought was lsquois this a scam rsquoldquoThe outside of the envelope said it was from Buckingham Palace and when you opened the letter it said Her Majesty invites you to be the recipient of the Maundy money.ldquoIt just seemed so wild and asit was not true but then Margaret got the same letter and I realised that it was right.ldquoIt just blew my head away.ldquoIrsquove seen the Queen handing out the Maundy money down the years and I never in my wildest dreams imagined that I would get it.Seventy-five-year-old Alan, an elder at the Parish of Traprain for more than  years, was due to travel to the service, which was to take place on April , with his we, Eleanor.At the service, each recipient would be given two purses, one red ndash containing a pound coinand a p piece representing the GB Olympic Team ndash and one white .Due to the coronavirus and travelling and gathering restrictions, both Alan and Margaret received their purses in the post.Margaret, originally an elder at Whittingehame Parish Church before it became part of the Parish of Traprain in , had planned to make the trip south with her daughter, Susan.The former housekeeper at Abbeyfield House in East Linton was ldquodisappointed not to be able to attend the event at Windsor but stressed these were exceptional circumstances.She
