title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-dirleton-dunbar-east-linton-east-lammermuir-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonTHE Dirleton Area Resilience Teamcontinues to serve its community, with requests to pick up shopping and prescriptions still coming in.It has also launched a new booking system to allow it to better serve its community and protect its volunteers.Its essentials community larder continues to flourish and has seen an entertainment section added.It now stocks books, CDs, DVDs and board games, with sections for both adults and children.Generous donations continue to be made of special food items such as crumbles, bakery treats and soups.DART is working with both the Saltire and Hi Awards, youth volunteer programmes that have allowed the group to include volunteering activities for young people.The Saltire Award is available for young people aged -.It is a nationally credited award that goes towards Scottish Credit and Qualications Framework .Volunteers will be allowed to be a part of DART and help complete requests such as delivering leaflets and fulfilling customer orders.The Hi Awards are for children aged five to . DART will be offering children between these ages at-home volunteering opportunities, such as letter writing and art, which will be sent to those self-isolating and shielding in the village.David Tait, lead co-ordinator for DART, said: ldquoWe now have a great opportunity for the youth in our community to feel part of this amazing organisation.ldquoWith the addition of the awards being nationally recognised and accredited, it was a no-brainer to follow through on this opportunity.ldquoIf any of our youth are interested in the Saltire or Hi Awards, please email your enquiry to Dart.Coordinators@outlook.Contact detailsIf you are in need of assistance, contactDART.coordinators@outlookor call .DunbarDunbarA FRIENDLY voice at the other end of the phone is being offered to people on their own during lockdown.Community resilience volunteers in Dunbar are urging people to get in touch evenit is simply for a chat.The townrsquos volunteers are already offering a range of services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions.In addition, there is also a chance for people to simply talk to someone. George Robertson, a member of the townrsquos community council and chairman of the Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , stressed the importance of the service.He said: ldquoIt is a really important aspect to the whole thing. I think it will become increasingly important as people get a bit stir crazy.ldquoObviously, a lot of people have friends and family nearby but there are quite a few who do not.ldquoWe need to be conscious that sometimes they are reluctant to ask for help.ldquoWe need to be vigilant for anyone looking for help so we can give a bit of TLC, support, help or a friendly voice on the end of the phone.George has been at the heart of the resilience efforts in the town. Dunbar, along with neighbouring West Barns, has been split into dferent sections, with a lead volunteer in each of the areas.The lead volunteers for the nine clusters ndash Shore and Harbour Group High Street, Parsonspool to Kings Court West End to Countess Road Belhaven and Kirk Park West Barns and the Beveridge Row development Queenrsquos Road and the new housing developments Hallhill, Kellie Road and to the railway line Brodie Road east and north to the railway line and Brodie Road west and north to the railway line ndash have an online meeting each fortnight to checkthere are any issues.George said: ldquoWe are still getting regular requests for shopping, prescriptions and the like.ldquoThere are also a few people who just ring up for a chat.ldquoThat is all ticking along quite nicely.Attention is also turning to how the community copes when lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A number of volunteers willto work as businesses reopen but George was confident that Dunbar and West Barns would continue to be there for people in need.He previously had to draw up a reserve list for volunteers when the coronavirus pandemic started and said there would be enough people to continue to offer support.Contact detailsFor more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers at facebook groups  or Dunbar Community Council at facebook Dunbar CommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderSHOPPING and prescriptions continue to be collected for residents in East Linton and surrounding villages.The Dunpender community resilience team, like many across the county, is offering a iety of services to help people in need during the coronavirus crisis.Judith Priest, chairwoman of the villagersquos community council, said things remained quiet but they were thereanyone was in need of assistance.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus is available on the Tyninghame Village Hall website ndash tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk ndash as well as on eastlinton.uk.Last month, a flyer was delivered to each home in the area, which offered assistance in terms of shopping, prescriptions or people looking to talk to someone.For more information, call   and  .Stenton.kim traynor and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.East LammermuirTEAMS of volunteers are keeping in touch with each other throughout East Lothian to ensure they are helping people the best they can.Resilience groups have been set up in towns and villages throughout the county during the coronavirus outbreak.Volunteers have come forward to help vulnerable members of the community with any assistance they need.Chris Bruce, chairman of East Lammermuir Community Council, said they were continuing to work together.The community council covers villages including Spott, Stenton, Innerwick and Oldhamstocks.Mr Bruce said: ldquoThere is a pretty good network of email contact, and people follow up with phone callsthere is something particular.ldquoIt is right across East Lothian and is really good.Contact detailsMore information on the help available in the East Lammermuir area is available from the grouprsquos website, eastlammermuircommunitycouncil.org.uk, which also contains a list of the community councillors.Gullane. Picture: Google MapsGullaneA NEW website has been set up to provide people in Gullane with the latest information relating to the coronavirus.The Gullane Resilience Team, made up of volunteers from throughout the village, have been working hard since the outbreak of restrictions due to the global pandemic.Now, a dedicated website has been set up to keep people up-to-date.A spokesman for the villagersquos resilience team said: ldquoThe Gullane Resilience Team have continued to serve the community but have noticed a settling down of demand.ldquoLorna Scott, our co-ordinator, has worked extremely hard and is developing the village hub for the distribution of food, the exchange of DVDs and childrenrsquos games every Tuesday, noon to pm, and Friday, .am to am.ldquoSeveral face shields were donated by Alun Joseph and were passed on to the Gullane Medical Centre and the Muirfield care home.ldquoBoth have reported that they are delighted with them.ldquoA new website, GullaneRT, has been set up which contains all the information regarding how our resources are being deployed and the services that can be provided by the team.Contact detailsFor more information, visit www.gullanert or contact the team on GullaneRteam@gmail or by telephoning  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Day Centre may be closed to its members due to the coronavirus crisis, but it is making sure they are being looked after in their homes.Some  of the day centrersquos  members are receiving sandwich lunches.The centre was established  years ago to improve the quality of le for older people who live independently in and around North Berwick.Normally, members would be brought to the centre by its own specially adapted bus once or twice a week.Now, its nine staff are delivering  lunches, five days a week, and all members are also getting free copies of the East Lothian Courier, thanks to the North Berwick resilience group fund.Care assistant Lisa Robertson said a lot of members were getting their lunch every day and those celebrating birthdays were also getting a special treat.In the past eight weeks, five members have received sweet treats to celebrate their birthdays, with the most recent being a -year-old woman.The Day Centre is also handing out quizzes, games and jigsaws to members, as well as having a chat on doorsteps ndash at a safe distance ndash where possible.Lisa said so far all of the centre members have stayed in good health but they are lonely and missing meeting other people.A team of around  volunteers are contacting members by telephone to have a chat and also find outany other help is needed.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Councilrsquos resilience group fund is being used to help volunteers get ready-made meals delivered to vulnerable residents in the town three days per week.Community council chair Judy Lockhart has arranged for voluntary organisation Home-Start East Lothian to provide two-course meals at a cost of pound. a day, and is using the fund to subsidise them for people wanting a meal every day of the week.As a result, someone wanting seven meals a week will only have to pay pound.The resilience fund can also offer financial assistance to those who need money to pay for these meals.Contact detailsPeople wishing to sign up for the service should phone the resilience group helpline on   or email communityresilience@northberwickcommunitycouncil.org.ukOr you can visitwww.nbresilience

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-garvald-gifford-haddington-macmerry-gladsmuir-pencaitland-tranent-elphinstone
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at six of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Garvald.M J Richardson and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.GarvaldCOMMUNITY spirit has been praised in a rural part of East Lothian which is tackling the coronavirus.Garvald and Morham Community Council was one of the first to produce an emergency resilience plan, with the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team also being established.Since then, a leaflet has been hand delivered to each of the properties, with information also put online to keep people up-to-date with what is happening.Penny Short, co-ordinator of the Garvald Emergency Resilience Team, noted there were a number of issues they had to overcome, including the remoteness of some people living in the area.She said: ldquoBefore the coronavirus epidemic and subsequent lockdown hit we had already hand delivered a leaflet to every address in our ward explaining who we were and what the team could do, so that everyone in our area knew who to contactthey needed any help.ldquoOur team members have a WhatsApp Group and we keep in touch through that.ldquoSocial media has been a blessing through this time of social distancing!ldquoOnce lockdown was in place I set up a private Facebook page called Garvald Community which is for residents only.ldquoThis is a safe, supportive place where people can ask for help or assistance and hopefully find helpful advice and information such as messages from the government or information on food deliveries.ldquoInformation on food deliveries is pretty important as Garvald doesnrsquot have any shopsand for people who are self-isolating or shielding these food deliveries are essential.ldquoWe contacted ious food suppliers and co-ordinated delivery days and then passed on the details to the villagers.However, it is not just through social media that the group has reached out to people.An online form, which people can fill in outlining how they need assistance, is available on the villagersquos website.Penny added: ldquoWe are aware of any vulnerable people in our area and we are connected with our residents ndash whether through the Garvald Community Facebook page, the website or the villagersquos Neighbourhood Watch Scheme.ldquoBecause we are pretty remote and used to being cut off in bad weather our community is already pretty resilient and has always been supportive to everyone in the village.ldquoBut our wonderful community spirit has never been more evident than right now as everyone has come together to help each other and provide support with shopping, collecting prescriptions, offers of dog walking and other ways to help each other.ldquoWe have recently launched a group to make face masks for locals and lsquoscrubs bagsrsquo for NHS and care workers.ldquoNot for the first time I am so grateful to stay in Garvald and so proud of our fantastic community."Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.garvald.org.ukGford. Picture: Google MapsGfordGIFFORD volunteers this week trialled a new Soup And A Smile delivery service as they took hot lentil soup, a buttered roll and a fruit scone to households where there are older residents living alone.The plan is to provide lunch one day a week, as well as catch up with residents while observing social distancing rules.Nicola Goddard, from Lanterne Rouge cafeacute, offered her services to support the volunteer activity, which is provided free to the households.A spokesperson for Gford Community Council said: ldquoThe feedback is already very positive both regarding the fabulous quality of the food and the concept.ldquoOur delivery team worked quickly and observed all protocols to deliver the food to households. Wersquore gathering more feedback as we look to provide this on a weekly basis.This week, the team has also been sourcing face coverings for volunteers, to offer them extra confidence when undertaking tasks on behalf of households.Lanterne Rouge donated a supply of lsquobuffsrsquo and local resident and designer Ellie Thomson is making the coverings from her home.The community council said a request for cotton fabric, thread and elastic generated a fantastic response and they are currently trying to source additional elastic.They have also written to Homes For Le Housing Partnership, which oversees social housing flats in the village, after discovering families living there were unable to use their drying greens as gardens.They said: ldquoWe are very lucky in Gford to have a lot of open green space surrounding us.ldquoWe became aware through some tenants in social housing flats that they are unable to use drying greens as garden space for their children.ldquoWe have written to Homes For Le to ask that this situation is revisited so all children can have access to safe outdoor space on their doorstep.ldquoWe received a positive response from the organisation and hope that the guidance can be claried to benefit families in the village.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers are looking to the future to ensure people continue to receive assistance once lockdown restrictions are relaxed.A squad of volunteers in Haddington have been helping with everything from collecting food and prescriptions to walking dogs and simply providing someone for people to talk to.However, the resilience team is now planning for the future to ensure there are still plenty of volunteers available as lockdown is eased.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, has been at the heart of the resiliency efforts.He said: ldquoWe are now starting to put plans together for coming out of quarantine.ldquoFor a lot of us in the coming weeks, we will be coming out of lockdown but for our elderly residents they will probably still be in lockdown.ldquoWe are starting to plan to make sure everybody is taken care of post lockdown.Currently, many of the volunteers are off their work and able to help throughout the town.However, as businesses reopen and peopleto work, it reduces the amount of free time people have.Chris said it was important to ensure there were still volunteers available to help people who continued to be at home.The group experienced an increase in calls in the last week, with the community council vice-chairman putting it down to many people reaching the end of the month in terms of their wages.He said: ldquoFor some folk it was the end of the month and we were getting an increase in calls about food.ldquoWe have done a few things over the weekend and a couple of things to make sure people have good food, that they are covered and they are not starving themselves.Chris praised the efforts of Our Community Kitchen, who are based in the townrsquos bowling club.The team of volunteers are delivering hot meals to people throughout the town to ensure no-one is going hungry.One other issue Chris pointed to was the increased need in terms of help with gardening.He added: ldquoWith the rain and sunshine over the past week, peoplersquos gardens have started growing.ldquoWe have got in touch with some gardeners, who are going out to help people this week.Contact detailsFor more information, go to www.haddingtoncc.org.uk or call   , between am and pm.Macmerry. Picture: Google MapsMacmerry and GladsmuirTHE Macmerry and Gladsmuir Community Resilience Team are encouraging local residents to continue making pom poms, and are on the lookout for more supplies.In the past two weeks,  craft packs containing equipment necessary to make the pom poms have been distributed, with a number of adults joining in alongside the villagesrsquo children.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, told the Courier that volunteers have put ribbons up along the school gates for people to hang their finished pom poms from.He said: ldquoWersquove had about  packs handed out already and people have started making them.ldquoPeople are encouraged to go along to the school and tie their pom poms to the ribbons.He added: ldquoSince itrsquos started itrsquos become quite colourful and is really nice to see.ldquoThe whole point is to show off community support it will also show and encourage people who are from Macmerry or travelling through that we are supporting frontline workers, whether that be from the NHS, emergency service workers or supermarket staff.ldquoWe are trying to bring back that feel-good factor into the villages, when all we seem to have is bad news.One resident has decided to hang plastic balls of dferent colours outside her house as part of the project.Anyone willing to donate wool, of any quality although double knit is preferred, or anyone needing assistance is asked to call  .Collection or pick up of wool donations can also be arranged.Meanwhile, the resilience team were joined by a couple of new volunteers in the past week, and they will help to deliver the continuing resilience effort.Stevie said the resilience group have put together a contingency plan, should the virusin the future, which will allow the effort to start back up again more quickly and smoothly.He said: ldquoWersquove put a kind of plan in place, forthis all goes away then comes back again.ldquoWe now have an admin system that could be started upneeded.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, atfacebook groups   andtwitter MacmerryTeamPencaitland. Picture: Google MapsPencaitlandTHE response from residents in Pencaitland and its surrounding area to an appeal for volunteers has been described as ldquophenomenal by community council chairman Ralph Averbuch.Before lockdown had even been introduced, Pencaitland Community Council was preparing for what was coming with an early call for help.Now they have  volunteers working in a resilience network of support for the communityrsquos most vulnerable families and residents.Ralph said: ldquoOn March , it was already looking like we were approaching unprecedented events in modern times.ldquoIt was still a week away from local schools being closed and social distancing really kicking in however, unprecedented times require unprecedented measures and in Pencaitland and District that involved a call for volunteers.ldquoWe needed to be ready, and quickly, for whatever was coming.ldquoMost calls for community participation in ordinary times generate next to no response.ldquoPeople are busy with their own lives and family work concerns so lsquocommunityrsquo, for most, almost always takes a back seat.ldquoYet, when the call went out for volunteers, the response was nothing short of phenomenal.ldquoWithin  hours we had  people signed up and ready to do whatever needed to be done.ldquoFrom this start, we were able to begin a process of organising volunteers into geographic clusters, each with their own lead co-ordinators.ldquoNothing like this has happened in any of our letimes, yet, when the situation really demanded that people step up and be counted, there was no shortage of volunteers willing and able to help, from people in their teens to those in their s.ldquoWe are now a resilience network of . Had I been asked at the start how many people would come forward Irsquod have thought Irsquod be able to count them on one hand.ldquoThe good news is when itrsquos really important and people know it, there is no shortage of volunteers wanting to help solve our problems.Contact detailsAnyone living in or around the Pencaitland area and seeking assistance, or just wanting to help out, in the first instance can call Community Council chair Ralph on   or email him at covid@pencaitland.org.Additionally, Pencaitland  District Coronavirus Emergency Helpers have a Facebook page ndash facebook groups   ndash where you can get in touchyou want to help with the massive volunteer effort.Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranent and ElphinstoneTRANENT and Elphinstone Community Council is starting to think about how it will continue delivering its resilience effort once lockdown restrictions start to be relaxed.Member Mike Falconer is the grouprsquos single point of contact and is overseeing the local resilience effort.He told the Courier that, once restrictions begin to lt, people will still need support so the resilience effort will still be needed, something he said could be described as ldquocontingency planning.He said: ldquoWe canrsquot just stop the need is still going to be there.ldquoThe lt of restrictions is going to be gradual [rather than all at once] and we need to think how we are going to manage and maintain the resilience effort and some sort of support.He added that there is not a plan in place, as such, but the community council ldquohas got its eye on it.Meanwhile, it is business as usual and residents who need assistance continue to get the help they need.Mike said: ldquoItrsquos exactly the same and we are carrying on doing what we are doing, delivering food, walking dogs and picking up prescriptions.ldquoWersquove got a routine established and are just carrying on delivering it until we are told to stop.The resilience effort is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsThose who need assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmail

title: marking-75-years-since-ve-day
story: The Bank Holiday was moved from Mondayto today , to allow people to celebrate.In East Lothian, council staff and schools were granted an additional dayrsquos leave to allow them to mark the occasion.Many events and commemorations initially scheduled have had to be cancelled or scaled back due to the ongoing coronavirus outbreak and subsequent lockdown, with people unable to come together, celebrate, remember and give thanks in person.Some of the commemorations taking place today include a two-minute silence at am, playing of the Last Post at .pm and the Nations Toast at pm, in whicheveryone is asked to raise a glass and toast the heroes of World War Two.East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant Michael Williams has also suggested ways people can remember the day.He said: ldquoGiven the current global pandemic crisis we face due to Covid-, many of the planned celebrations and acts of remembrance planned across East Lothian have been cancelled or changed to reflect the need to keep the nation safe.ldquoHowever, commemorating this historic event from home or the work place is still encouraged as best as we can.ldquoIt can be a time for everyone in East Lothian to remember the immeasurable sacrices that were made at home and abroad and to celebrate  years of victory and peace in Europe.Some of these activities include the thousand plus pipers taking part on Battlersquos Orsquoer at pm, town criers, and members of the public,crying out for peace at .pm and the Queenrsquos televised address at pm, the same time her father King George VI gave a radio address  years ago.The Battles Oer event sees thousands of pipers performing the song, traditionally played at the end of a battle.As well as the cry for peace, bells in churches and cathedrals will ring at pm in a collective celebration of peace.Mr Williams also highlighted several VE Day television shows, the list can be viewed at spark.adobe page eceXXfFlyGV The Royal British Legion has also created a programme of activities, including a livestream on Facebook .am-noon and an evening of music and memories in partnership with BBC from pm.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, East Lothian Councilrsquos Armed Forces Champion, said: ldquoIt is hard to imagine the experiences and sacrices that were made during wartime on our behalf.ldquoHowever I believe that our current perspective will give us an even greater appreciation for those who served and supported the war effort and their communities who prayed, and mourned their loved ones.ldquoWhile our commemorations may be dferent to previous years, and to those that were originally envisaged, they will be no less heartfelt and sincere.Meanwhile, East Lothian Council and its community planning partners have signed a covenant to support the armed forces community living in the county.It is an agreement between the council, the community planning partnership and armed forces community in East Lothian.It recognises the issues experienced by the armed forces community locally and is a commitment to work together to address them.

title: seek-help-medical-emergencies
story: YESTERDAY, May , marked the th anniversary of VEDay, remembering the surrender of the Nazis and the end of the Second World War.I hope you joined me in paying tribute to surviving veterans and in commemorating those lost during the conflict.I am very grateful for the enduring peace achieved across Europe since .Although we might not have been able to take part in our usual commemorations, there was an online service led by Legion Scotland and Poppyscotland, which included a message from children and families currently learning at home and a video message of thanks from the First Minister.I am glad that measures were taken to honour this important anniversary, and to remember those who lost their lives.There has been a large reduction in the number of stroke patients, with AEs and stroke wards signicantly quieter since the beginning of the Covid- pandemic.We must not forget that a stroke is a medical emergency and,you see someone displaying stroke symptoms, it is still important to immediately dial .This is not the only medical emergency that you should seek support on ndashyou have any urgent symptoms that are not coronavirus related, you should still seek assistance from a GP or hospital.The NHS is still here for us and will continue to support those who need it.The Scottish Government has recommended thatyou are in an enclosed public space, such as a supermarket, then you should consider using something to cover your face.As well as this, you must also maintain a two-metre distance from those outside your household.It is important to note that covering your face does not necessarily mean that you need a medical grade face mask ndash something such as a scarf would also suffice.As we continue working together to overcome the Covid- pandemic, it is important that we continue to take social distancing measures seriously and I would recommend keeping up to date with the Scottish Government and NHS advice.

title: must-return-fairer-world-says-mp
story: MINDS are turning to le post-coronavirus, though itrsquoll still be a while before lockdown is even partially lted. But some of the enforced changes have suited some.Irsquove a few friends nearing retirement age and, enjoying the change in pace of le, have decided to retire early. It doesnrsquot suit everyone and itrsquos not available for many but, for those to whom it does apply, I say good luck.But there are other aspects that apply to us all. The Irish President, Michael D Higgins, made a remarkable speech about how both a better country and a fairer world need to come from this. Those sentiments and that ambition must apply here, as well as across the Irish Sea.When this is over, itrsquos about rewarding fairly those who have, not just throughout this crisis but always, worked hard in dficult circumstances.Itrsquos decent pay and conditions, as much as applause, that NHS staff, carers and council workers deserve. Despite the rhetoric about all of us being in this together, the poor have been suffering the most and that too must change.As well as in our economy and society though, the change must also be in our natural environment. Theof wildle has been joyful and the improvement in air quality a revelation.The latterrsquos something wersquove often taken for granted but for those with a lung or heart problem itrsquos a daily concern.The images of pollution fading across countries is astonishing but the freshness wersquore feeling in our lungs is something we need to retain.We canrsquot simply go back to le the way it was. When the coronavirus crisis is over, the climate change crisis will remain.We need to cherish the improvements that have come about, but remember the huge challenges that still exist, in ensuring our planetrsquos habitable for future generations.It wonrsquot be either easy or simple but the sacrices made by so many and the limited pleasures wersquove had as a result of it, must be a spur to deliver that better country and fairer world.

title: former-power-station-site-become-covid-19-testing-centre
story: East Lothian Council has confirmed that the former Cockenzie Power Station site will be opened and operated by the military as part of the UK Governments Covid- testing programme.No date for when it will start operations has been revealed but it is likely to be within the next week as testing is ramped up as part of plans to ease the current lockdown.It will be the first Covid- testing site of its kind in East Lothian, where an assessment centre has also been operating in Musselburgh since the start of April.The site, which was bought by the local authority from ScottishPower and is currently being marketed for economic investment, was offered up as a potential testing location by the council.The unit will be managed and staffed by military personnel, who would be responsible for its safe operation.Military staff will make appropriate use of PPE and no equipment will be left on site whilst the facility is closed.The council said it expects the facility to operate as a self-contained, drive-through facility. People will remain in their vehicle whilst being tested. Initially, it is understood it would operate over two, three-day periods.Tom Reid, the councils head of infrastructure, said: ldquoWe were asked to identy a potentially suitable site for a drive-through, mobile testing facility to be located."The former Cockenzie Power Station site was identied as a site which could be operated safely by military personnel."This facility would enable key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms to undergo testing, which is a vital component of the national response to tackling Covid-."East Lothian Council will continue to play its part and work with partners locally and nationally in dealing with the challenges posed by the emergency.The facility will provide tests for key workers who are self-isolating due to them or household members displaying symptoms.It is understood key workers and their family members will be eligible for testing.Key workers who are, or have a family member who is, symptomatic, can sign up via thehttps:self-referral.test-for-coronavirus.service.gov.uk portal.Cockenzie power stations famous twin chimneys were demolished in a controlled explosion in September, , two years after it had closed. The power station had opened in .

title: costa-coffee-starbucks-mcdonalds-get-green-light-reopen-drive-thrus
story: Ahead of an anticipated relaxation of the lockdown rules, the Environment Secretary has said drive-thru restaurants such as McDonaldrsquos are ldquomade for social distancing.At the Downing Street press conference on Friday, George Eustice said it was safe for takeaway food shops to reopen.Many familiar high street chains including McDonaldrsquos, Greggs and KFC chose to shut their doors during the lockdown.What did the Environment Secretary say When asked about fast-food stores reopening, Mr Eustice said: ldquoI think our view is that probably a McDonaldrsquos drive-thru is made for the social distancing situation we are in, in that people do not leave their car, they place their order and someone passes a bag of food to them at the end through a kiosk.Unlike many other businesses, fast-food outlets were not mandated to close during the lockdown.Some chains have begun to reopenSome restaurants have begun the process of reopening, with KFC opening around  of its branches for delivery or drive-thru.McDonaldrsquos has conducted trials on reopening stores, with  restaurants opening for deliveries from next week.Askedoutlets could have stayed open during the crisis, Mr Eustice said: ldquoWhile clearly restaurants and pubs had to close, we were quite keen to keep that capacity to be able to do takeaway food for people.He suggested reduced footfall in town centres, staff anxiety and a sense of what was ldquosocially acceptable given the stay-at-home message had led to places such as McDonaldrsquos and KFC closing.Mr Eustice added: ldquoI think it is quite possible for these venues to reopen and reopen safely, we never mandated that they should close.ldquoI think some of those food-to-go businesses will probably be seeking to learn lessons from what supermarkets have done as they consider tentatively reopening.New safety measures have been introduced at food outletsBefore reopening, the McDonaldrsquos restaurants will be deep cleaned, while new safety measures will be introduced such as Perspex screens and floor markings.Staff will also receive protective equipment, such as non-medical grade face masks, and have their temperatures taken with ldquocontactless thermometers before shts.Earlier this month Greggs pulled back on plans to reopen its first sites to the public next week over fears it could attract crowds.The highly popular bakery chain announced it would carry out the opening trial behind closed doors over fears customers will flock in large numbers.

title: itv-reveal-run-episodes-emmerdale-coronation-street
story: It comes after the number of shows broadcast each week were cut back to make the bank of recorded episodes last longer after production on both soaps was suspended in March.When are episodes We will be very careful and mindful about that sort of thing.Lygo said that while viewership is up in daytime, it is not up in peak time and he is worried about shedding viewers over the summer when the schedule is filled with repeats.He said this is why he is particularly anxious to get the soaps back on air, adding: ldquoI donrsquot want anyone who has been watching the soaps for years thinking lsquoOh I have done without it, maybe Irsquoll detox and Irsquoll get some le backrsquo.ldquoNo. Please donrsquot do that. title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!

title: coronavirus-scotland-top-ten-places-visit-lockdown-according-chaotic-scot-travel-blogger
story: Isle of Coll ndash from the peaceful village of Arinagour and the stunning white sand beaches, to the exceptional food and hospitality at Coll Hotel, this island really stole my heart. Coll is also a designated Dark Sky area so by night yoursquoll have stars in your eyes. Dunkeld ndash this pretty Perthshire town is best visited in autumn, where you can admire the vibrant trees on walk along the River Tay or through the forest at The Hermitage. For a wee treat, I go straight to the Scottish Deli or ARAN Bakery. Isle of Barra ndash the famous beach landing is one of my favourite travel experiences ever, and you wonrsquot find better fish curry and scallop pakora than at Cafeacute Kisimul. When I first saw the beaches on Vatersay, I couldnrsquot believe I was still in Scotland! Cullen ndash this picturesque seaside town is as charming as they come, from the cute harbour and fishermanrsquos cottages to the iconic arches of the old viaduct. I love walking along the coast to pretty Findochty or to the ruins of Findlater Castle. Isle of Eigg ndash you wonrsquot find friendlier locals than on this community-owned gem of an island. My best memories are climbing An Sgurr and walking up in Cleadale Bothy to views of the Singing Sands and the Jurassic-like Isle of Rum. Ardnamurchan ndash truly wild and untouched, this remote peninsula is the perfect place to just get away from it all. Sanna Bay is a sight to behold, and you can go inside Ardnamurchan Lighthouse at the most westerly point on the British mainland. Isle of Iona ndash possibly the most beautul and peaceful place on Earth. I love visiting the ancient abbey, climbing Dun I for views across the island, or taking a trip to Staffa to see the puffins. Oh, and dinner at Argyll Hotel is something special! Glen Coe ndash I challenge you to find a more dramatic and atmospheric place in Scotland. Glen Coe looks good in all weathers, at any time of year. Glencoe Lochan is a favourite spot on mine, then itrsquos off to the historic Clachaig Inn for a hearty meal and a few drams. Shetland ndash these rugged islands are the most northerly in Scotland closer to Scandinavia than the Scottish mainland. For a lesson in the history and culture, explore the well-preserved ruins at Jarlshof or join the crazy Viking celebrations at Up Helly Aa. Easdale Island ndash push a button in a wee shed to summon the motor boat lsquoferryrsquo over to this tiny island. There are no cars, so wheelbarrows are used to transport supplies, and the flooded slate quarries are local swimming pools. Such a special wee place!

title: Country Life  Rambling  reminiscing     and following the coronavirus code
story: On the gravelly, rocky trails up to the hilltops walkers pull into heathery lay-bys to allow others to pass. Almost everyone abides by the coronavirus code, which carries an echo of the police speed awareness course I was once obliged to attend. ldquoOnly a fool ignores the two second rule," went the jingle for keeping your distance from the vehicle in front. Breaking the new rules could be even more hazardous.Everyone extols the virtues of regular walking, and to judge by peoplersquos faces and mood, itrsquos doing us good. Therersquos nothing like having your liberty taken to encourage you to get outdoors while you can. A favourite walk follows an old drove road, along which herders would drive their beasts to market, either locally or in the north of England. Wide, and partially cobbled, this route allows you to get into a stride, while scanning trees and sky, or field upon field of horses and their winter foals.A drove road like this could be as old as the village, or even older. Hoolet was officially granted permission to hold a market in the early s, so itrsquos possible that from miles around people traded their animals to and from here along tracks such as this. One of the commonest books yoursquoll find in second-hand book shops is A R B Haldanersquos The Drove Roads of Scotland.Regrettably I have lost my fatherrsquos copy, but have a sellotaped edition of my husbandrsquos. First published in , it looks off-puttingly dry and yet it offers a riveting insight into a way of le so long gone as to feel mythical. By way of research, Haldane spoke to shepherds, farmers, crofters and factors to mine them for local knowledge. The result is a testament to the part livestock and their keepers have played in our history.A colourful passage from a Victorian onlooker describes a livestock ldquotryst at Stenhousemuir, where around , sheep and tens of thousands of cattle were gathered. He writes of the tar pots used to mark sold beasts, the cacophony of cattle dealers, drovers, pedlars, gamblers, ballad singers and beggars, and of servants ldquorunning about shouting to the cattle, keeping them together in their particular lots and ever and anon cudgels are at work upon the horns and rumps of the restless animals that attempt to wander in search of grass or water. Such a welter of beasts recalls the great buffalo herds in the American mid-west, and the drama, and danger, of keeping them under control.Did such a multitude of hooves ever thunder past the village  The old track is so tranquil, despite the orchestration of birds, itrsquos hard to imagine its former use. But I find that is the case with almost everything about country le. Books, newspapers and documentaries constantly inform us about tempting rural walks we can take for our health and pleasure, and walking during lockdown has enjoyed a resurgence in the same way as biking. Yet well into the th century people from a hamlet like ours, and all across the country, walked for miles every day: not as a hobby or to keep fit, but because it was their only means of transport.The picturesque village of Denholm, not far away, is the birthplace of the famous linguist John Leyden. As a young man he once walked  miles in a day, just to record the final verses of a song to add to Sir Walter Scottrsquos compendium of border ballads. The shepherd James Hogg would think nothing of crossing the hills of an evening from the Ettrick valley to Tibbie Shielsrsquo Inn by St Maryrsquos Loch, to carouse with friends. Itrsquos a round trip of over  miles. When his household needed provisions from Selkirk, the nearest town, that would entail another -mile jaunt. Presumably a mule or pony was used for such a distance  But even for the four-legged, that is quite a schlepp.Another legendary walker was Thomas de Quincey, a forerunner of the redoubtable Captain Tom Moore. In the s he planned to cure himself of his ldquoopium misery by walking himself fit, but at this precise moment his legs failed him. His doctorrsquos warnings were dire and, fearing thathe didnrsquot cure himself he would be disabled for the rest of his le, he took to the garden of his cottage near Lasswade. Measuring its perimeter, he estimated  laps came to a mile. Starting out cautiously, he gradually grew stronger. Soon he was doing  or  miles a day until, he wrote, ldquoI had within ninety days walked  miles". While he lived here, his medical student lodger trudged seven miles to Edinburgh University and back every day, so commonplace an occurrence it was barely worth remarking on.Itrsquos easy to look back on the great distances country folk covered with pity as well as awe, but as any serious walker knows, few things are more enjoyable ndash in decent weather ndash than clocking up the miles. There are moments when you feel like a piece of machinery, the cogs and wheels working in unison. Itrsquos also a failsafe way of clearing the mind, and finding fresh inspiration. Whenever my husband is stuck for the next sentence, he heads out. The top of every article or chapter he writes should record the tally of miles walked between first word and last.Itrsquos no wonder so many writers have been walkers. Not all were obliged to tramp the hills and roadside every day but many, like Robert Louis Stevenson, recognised the therapeutic benefits. He didnrsquot want to scale the heights, or keep to a strict and demanding schedule. A steady pace was his aim because, ldquoonce you have fallen into an equable stride, it requires no conscious thought from you to keep it up, yet it prevents you from thinking earnestly of anything ...

title: coronavirus-scotland-enjoy-cairngorms-comfort-armchair
story: The hotels, bars and restaurants are quiet, the visitors are at home. Even the Boat of Garten osprey nest seems to be missing its usual occupants.Water sports at Loch Morlich and Loch Insh are on hold, and the winding road up to Cairngorm Mountainrsquos ski area has been taken over by the resident reindeer herd.The mountains, lochs, forest trails and attractions that span the Cairngorms ndash Scotlandrsquos outdoor playground ndash should have been bustling with visitors enjoying one of the best spells of springtime weather for years.Instead, even the BBCrsquos Springwatch programme, filmed from its Cairngorms hub and which showcases the area in all its natural glory, is staying away.Now, to help us all enjoy a flavour of Highland le, Cairngorms National Park has unveiled plans to bring the nature, sounds, culture and scenery that makes it so special to our homes.For  days from Friday, May , a series of online events will offer a flavour of Britainrsquos biggest national park, including special reports highlighting conservation work to protect endangered wildcats and capercaillies, fun quizzes, music and art.The online festival replaces the Cairngorms Nature BIG Weekend, an annual springtime celebration of the national park which typically sees dozens of free activities and first-hand experiences for visitors.Instead, every day from Friday onwards, the Cairngorms BIG  Days Of Nature will showcase the parkrsquos wildle and nature online, with special emphasis on how the natural world can help support our mental health and wellbeing.Along with traditional music from local artists, the  days of virtual events will include art classes offering tips for wildle drawing and interviews with people working on the frontline of nature conservation across the park.Lucy Ford, Cairngorms National Park Authority conservation engagement officer, said: ldquoIt was such a disappointment that the BIG Weekend had to be rolled over to  after all the hard work everyone had put in.ldquoUnable to invite people here in lockdown, we decided we would take the celebration to them.ldquoI am very excited about what we have planned. All the event providers have joined in and each day has a theme.ldquoThere are ideas and activities for the whole family.The  days of online events will spotlight Cairngormsrsquo ldquoat risk wildcats and capercaillies alongside less well-known rare scabious mining bees, found in only a handful of locations and which nest in burrows in the ground, and Kentish Glory moths.Identied as a conservation priority species, the moths are only found in the northeast, in areas of young birch such as moorland or regenerating woodland.There will also be special reports on the parkrsquos bats, alpine plants and peatland restoration.ldquoWe know that being exposed to nature is proven to have a positive effect on our mental wellbeing and so we will be featuring ideas and activities to get people involved from their own homes, added Ford.The role nature plays in mental health and wellbeing and tackling climate change will also be included in the festival, with a keynote talk from Chris Stark, chief executive of the Committee on Climate Change at the Cairngorms Climate Conference, along with films that spotlight landscape scale projects designed to help tackle the climate emergency.A film from Alzheimer Scotlandrsquos Tipi project will highlight how the outdoors can aid people living with dementia and their families, while arts events include music from traditional musicians Hamish Napier and Jenny Sturgeon.Sturgeon, who was due to be open the BIG Weekend with the Highland launch of her new work inspired by Nan Shepherdrsquos book The Living Mountain, said: ldquoNature and the natural world informs and inspires my music and is a great stress reliever.ldquoI grew up near the Cairngorms and walking in the hills and catching glimpses of species there is always a delight.ldquoNow more than ever the outdoors and watching wildle has taken on a new meaning.Cairngorms BIG  Days Of Nature begins on Friday, May . The full programme is available at www.cairngormsnaturebigweekend, or visit www.facebook cairngormsnatureHow to keep tabs on your Cairngorms favouritesMissing your spring visit to Cairngorms National Park  Herersquos how to stay in touch with whatrsquos going on.Reindeer talesWith paths and roads clear of traffic, the Cairngorms reindeer herd has been taking the easy route to new pastures and saving keepers the problem of scrambling through rough heather to reach them.Britainrsquos only free-ranging reindeer herd has also been welcoming delightfully cute calves, while an adoption programme has been launched to raise vital funds lost during lockdown.Regular updates, cute photographs and details of how to adopt a reindeer are posted on the Cairngorms Reindeer Herd Facebook page.Plant leA highlight of the Big  Days of Nature will be a short film highlighting Plantle Scotlandrsquos work in Cairngorms National Park.Due to be screened online on Saturday, it was partly filmed at Anagach Woods, where there are rare wintergreen, creeping ladyrsquos tresses, twinflower and stagrsquos horn clubmoss, the spores of which were once used to create magicianrsquos flash powder.The film includes an explanation of Gaelic plant names and film of tiny arctic alpine flowers flourishing on the windswept Cairngorms plateau.To follow Plantle Scotlandrsquos work in the Cairngorms, its floral s who monitor plants and its Cairngorms Wild Plants Project, go to www.plantle.org.uk scotland or like Plantle Scotland on Facebook.Beer and banterMissing a pint at the bar of the Cairngorm Hotel in Aviemore, a foot-tapping evening in front of a roaring fire with some fiddle music in the background, or just some glorious scenery The Pine Marten Bar and Scran at Glenmore has been treating Facebook followers to daily images of dazzling sunsets, Loch Morlich scenes and news updates with plenty of banter thrown in ndash including indoor skateboarding.Wash it down with a beer ordered online from the Cairngorm Brewery or a Speyside malt.Hit the hillsCairngorms National Parkrsquos website is calling for walkers to bag a Munro by signing up for its virtual challenge.Walk  minutes every day for six days to claim Ben Macdui, an hour a day for two days to bag Beinn arsquo Ghlo and  minutes for four days to add Lochnagar to your "done it" list.If cycling is your thing, Ride Cairngorm on Facebook is packed with pictures of bikes against stunning mountain scenery and the occasional competition.Bird leKeep on top of whatrsquos happening with the parkrsquos birdle by following RSPB Loch Garten Abernethyrsquos Facebook updates.Therersquos little news of ospreys nesting, but there is a species of the day feature, regular links to blogs and podcasts, and ideas to create wildle features in gardens.Brush up on your knowledge of birdsong by visiting Cairngorms National Parkrsquos website ndash therersquos a page dedicated to the sounds of the park.On the estateLynbreck Croft on the outskirts of Aviemore, spans  acres and is home to thistle-chomping pigs, a couple of Highland cows, chickens, bees and a tea plantation.Owners Sandra Baer and Lynn Cassells post regular vlogs and Facebook updates with plenty of pictures of le on the farm.Swing by Alvie Estate on Facebook too for regular news from the Kingussie area, images of days gone by and plenty of pictures of new arrivals on the farm.Meanwhile, Balmoral Castle and Estatersquos page is updated daily with photographs and news from the royal residence.

title: mysteries-history-can-identify-forgotten-photos
story: Some might be the streets we grew up in, country houses passed on the road to somewhere , crumbling factories where parents once worked or churches where grandparents worshipped.Captured in black and white, and with many showing streets remarkably clear of the traffic that would soon come, some , fascinating photographs of Scottish le taken during the s and s have presented Scots with the ultimate lockdown puzzle.Images taken by staff working for the long-defunct Scottish Development Department have been made available online for the first time by Historic Environment Scotland , along with an appeal to the public to turn detective and help identy the houses, streets and businesses they show.They may have their work cut out: the new online archive showcases rural and urban Scotland, from Highland crofts and Orkney farms to large housing estates in Fe, city tenements in Glasgow, unidentied town centre shops with old-fashioned signs and equally old-fashioned looking shoppers.While some may be easy to locate, others are likely to have viewers scratching their heads over where they may be.As well as providing Scots with a massive puzzle to solve, the collection of images offers a rare insight into what le was like throughout Scotland in years not that long gone by, with pub interiors, fashion trends and interior design choices also captured.One of the most striking elements of the outdoor photographs is the lack of vehicles travelling on Scottish roads, while others capture everyday elements of le which were familiar at the time but are now long gone ndash such as one image showing firemen dressed in their yellow waterproofs, shoppers queuing outside their local fishmonger, and children playing in the street on their Chopper bikes.Lesley Ferguson, head of archives at HES, said: ldquoPeople will find this collection really engaging. Sometimes history can be too far away, whereas this is history that people will remember.ldquoSome show buildings and others are just street scenes taken at a time when there were far fewer cars on the road.ldquoUnfortunately, we donrsquot know where some of these historic photographs were taken and thatrsquos why we are asking for the publicrsquos help.While the images have been digitised and uploaded to Canmore, the online catalogue of HES archives, it was felt it would be too time-consuming for HES staff to st through the , unidentied images in an effort to find their location.Instead itrsquos hoped that visitors to the Canmore website will come to the rescue and email details of locations and buildings to HES staff. The images will be alternated regularly to allow more photographs to be catalogued.The unidentied images are among around , plastic photographic negatives and some printed photographs contained within the HES Scottish Development Department collection, most of which contain information regarding the location where they were taken.Some relate to the development of Scotlandrsquos New Towns, while others show buildings in a state of disrepair and may be among the last photographs prior to the buildings being lost forever.Last year alone, over , items from the HES archives were digitised, among them prints relating to signicant archaeological digs and images of excavations at historic sites such as Skara Brae in Orkney and Edinburgh Castle.They included approximately , prints digitised from personal research and work by prominent archaeologists such as Dr Euan Mackie, Roger Mercer and Vere Gordon Childe, with the oldest image dating from around .Mackiersquos collection comprises field notes, photographs, drawings and ious research material collected during investigations of threatened sites including East Wemyss Caves and the Greenland, Auchentorlie prehistoric rock sculptures.Much of the collection derives from his s excavation and survey of brochs and duns, notably Dun Mor Vaul in Tiree, Dun Lagaidh, and Dun an Ruigh Ruadh in Lochbroom.Over one million archives documenting Scotlandrsquos archaeological sites, buildings, industry and maritime heritage are currently available on Canmore.Ferguson added: ldquoThese archives give a unique perspective on civic planning in the th century including the development and growth of Scotlandrsquos New Towns, while the images of excavations showcase the sites that helped archaeologists unlock the secrets of Scotlandrsquos past ndash from the Neolithic to the Middle Ages.ldquoBy digitising our archives, wersquore able to make them available to even more people. Digitisation helps us make heritage accessible to all as well as ensuring the long-term preservation of these important documents and photographs.bull To view a range of unidentied images from the Scottish Development Department archives, click here

title: whisky-tourism-can-key-scotlands-post-coronavirus-bounce-back-says-festival-chairman
story: By James CampbellWhen we wrapped our phenomenally successful Spirit of Speyside Festival  with plans in place for an even bigger and better collection of events in , we never could have imagined we would be where we are today. The festival has been cancelled and cultural gatherings across the country have been put on hold or postponed.It goes without saying that in these times our priority is the health and safety of our families, our loved ones ndash whether thatrsquos hugs with grandchildren, seeing friends or enjoying shared experiences such as the Spirit of Speyside Festival which should have been held last week. However, what I have witnessed emerging is hope, resilience and a strong Scottish can-do attitude. In the whisky industry, in particular, within days of lockdown being announced, distilleries rallied together to manufacture large quantities of vitally important hand sanitiser.Itrsquos a true testament to our Scottish fighting spirit that we will not take this lying down. We adapt and move forward as best we can. Irsquom extremely proud of the Speyside community and our wider Spirit of Speyside Festival family across the world for keeping the spirit of the festival alive.Whisky and tourism are pivotal sectors to the Scottish economy. Three out of every five tourists come to Speyside for whisky tourism. In fact, the Spirit of Speyside Festival welcomed visitors from  dferent countries to its th anniversary event last year. The Spirit of Speyside Whisky Festival has become an iconic event on the international whisky calendar, appealing to both the whisky curious and connoisseurs in a region that has become one of the fastest-growing tourist destinations in the UK.As well as being home to the highest concentration of distilleries of all whisky regions in the world, Speyside also produces the largest volume of whisky, as well as an increasingly wide range of spirits ndash we are now home to  dferent gin companies.This is why we introduced our Speyside Gin Festival in June, to create a new weekend for both locals and visitors to enjoy, then we celebrate all our great Speyside whisky companies and local gin and craft beer companies at our Distilled Festival, all under one roof in Elgin, normally at the end of August.This yearrsquos Gin Festival has sadly been cancelled and a decision is yet to be made about Distilled. However, based on current guidance, we feel itrsquos unlikely it will go ahead.But the appetite for whisky is there and it will remain. I am confident our economy will be rebuilt and we will work hard to do this together. According to VisitScotland, the Spirit of Speyside Festival welcomed visitors from  dferent countries to its th anniversary festival last year. This is a sector that is worth pound million to the regionrsquos economy. When we emerge from the other side of the pandemic Irsquom certain these figures will only increase.International travel is sure to take a downturn in the short term, while people look for local and regional travel opportunities on their doorstep. Domestic travel is set to be the first to bounce back when restrictions are eased, and I canrsquot wait to welcome tourists from all over the UK to beautul Speyside.Our Team Speyside approach to tourism will pull us through these tough times in our part of the world, of that I have no doubt. Our whisky distilleries will reopen, glasses will be raised to good health, and visitors from across the world will once again immerse themselves in Malt Whisky Country. Never will the term ldquoslaacuteinte mhaith hold more weight than it will when this is all over. Let us all toast to that this World Whisky Day on May .James Campbell, is the chairman, Spirit of Speyside Whisky FestivalRead more: First Look: Diageorsquos Edinburgh whisky tourism experience at nightRead more: Coronavirus: Tourism rallying call to help firms tackle crisis

title: coronavirus-scotland-new-legislation-aims-help-struggling-scots
story: Ministers said the new legislation will see an additionalpound. million investment in the Carerrsquos Allowance Supplement as well as extra protections for those facing bankruptcy.Meanwhilenotice to leave periods will be introduced for students in purpose-built student accommodation and halls of residence.The one-off pound. will be paid to carers in June alongside theexisting twice-yearly Carerrsquos Allowance Supplement of the same amount.The moveis expected to benefit , people.Constitutional Secretary Michael Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is determined to do all we can to help iniduals and businesses who are facing hardship as a result of this unprecedented crisis.ldquoThe Bill will help many people facing bankruptcy, adding to emergency measures which the Scottish Parliament has already approved.ldquoIt will also provide Scottish Ministers with the power to introduce reductions in non-domestic rates payable during  , and a wide range of changes necessary to support public services to continue to operate as they were intended during what are exceptional circumstances.ldquoThroughout this crisis we have tried to achieve consensus and will continue to work on a cross-party basis to enable the government to take the steps necessary to help Scotland get through these extraordinary times.Ministers said this means more people who find themselves in debt will be able to avoid a costly and y bankruptcy process.The Bill also contains recommended legislative changes in areas including non-domestic rates relief, proceeds of crime and the wider operation of Scotlandrsquos criminal justice system.Notice to leave periods will be introduced for students tied into existing contracts or those looking to enter into contracts for the next academic year in halls of residence and purpose-built student accommodation.The new Bill follows emergency legislation previously passed by the Scottish and UK Parliaments to assist in the response to the pandemic.The policy extends the window in which a repayment claim can be made from  months to  months.It aims to mitigate the effect on those who are unable to qualy for repayment of ADS within the normal -month period because of disruption in the housing market.The Scottish Fiscal Commission estimated this move will cost poundm, spread over three years.

title: coronavirus-european-countries-begin-easing-restrictions
story: All faced a delicate balance of trying to restart battered economies without fuelling a second wave of coronavirus infections.Social distancing was the order of the day but just how to do that on public transport and in schools was the big question.With Mondayrsquos partial reopening, the French did not have to carry forms allowing them to leave their homes but crowds quickly developed at some metro stations in Paris, one of Francersquos viral hotspots.:Coronavirus in Scotland: New legislation aims to help struggling ScotsA last-minute legal challenge emerged to the governmentrsquos practice of confining people to their own regions, further confusing the post-lockdown landscape.Antoinette van Zalinge, principal of the De Notenkraker elementary school in Amsterdam, wore a wide white skirt and a hula hoop slung from her shoulders and carried a long stick with a hand at one end so she could shake hands with students while still keeping . metresapart.In Paris, hairdressers practised their new workflow over the weekend ahead of Mondayrsquos reopening, and planned to charge a ldquoparticipation fee for the new disposable protective gear they will need for each customer.Walk-in customers will be a thing of the past, said Brigitte LrsquoHoste, manager of the Hair de Beaute salon, who expects the number of appointments to be cut in half.ldquoThe face of beauty will change, meaning clients wonrsquot come here to relax. Clients will come because they need to, said Aurelie Bollini, a beautician at the salon.ldquoThey will come and aim at getting the maximum done in the shortest time possible.Roughly half of Spainrsquos  million people stepped into a softer version of the countryrsquos strict confinement, beginning to socialise, shop in small stores and enjoy outdoor seating in restaurants and bars.Its biggest cities of Madrid and Barcelona remained under lockdown, however.Fears about new waves of infection have been born out in Germany, where a new cluster was linked to a slaughterhouse in Wuhan, the Chinese city where the virus started and in South Korea, where a single nightclub customer was linked to  new infections.The South Korean government pushed back hard against that wave, halting the school reopenings that had been planned for this week and reimposing restrictions on nightclubs and bars.It is now trying to track , people who had visited a popular Seoul entertainment district by checking credit card transactions, mobile phone records and security camera footage.In Germany, gyms reopened in the most populous state, but authorities there and in France have said any backsliding in the daily number of infections could lead to new restrictions.:Tories demand to see Sturgeons evidence for slower approach to lockdownldquoWersquore going to have to learn to live with the virus, health minister Olivier Veran said.The hurdles ahead for tourism and the service industries were clear, even in places where infections are diminished.Shanghai Disneyland reopened to visitors, but let in limited numbers and demanded that they wear face masks and have their temperatures checked.ldquoWe hope that todayrsquos reopening serves as a beacon of light across the globe, providing hope and inspiration to everyone, Shanghai Disney Resort president Joe Schott told reporters.In the US, Trump administration officials spoke optimistically about a relatively quick rebound from the pandemic ndash but then had to announce that vice president Mike Pence was self-isolating after one of his aides tested positive.US treasury secretary Steven Mnuchin predicted the American economy would rebound in the second half of this year from unemployment rates that rival the Great Depression.Another . million US workers applied for jobless benefits last week, bringing the total over seven weeks to . million unemployed.The US has seen . million infections and nearly , deaths, the most in the world by far, according to a tally by Johns Hopkins University.Worldwide, four million people have been reported infected and more than , have died, over , of them in Europe.Health experts believe all those numbers understate the true toll of the pandemic for dferent reasons.India reported its
