title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls keir starmers labour leadership win ray hope difficult times
story: The MP for Holborn and St Pancras defeated Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir, who won on the first round of voting with . per cent of ballots cast.Stephen called Sir Keirs ascension a ray of hope, and said that the party should now turn its attention to winning elections.He said: ldquoI am so pleased that Keir Starmer has become UK Labour leader.ldquoThe ray of hope Keir represents could not come at a more critical time.ldquoHis message of unity has won over members up and down the country ndash and we need to ensure that we model that through the whole of the UK Labour Party.ldquoAnd it is clear that Labour comes out of this contest stronger, with Rebecca and Lisa running really positive campaigns.ldquoThe UK General Election result in December was devastating for Labour and we cannot repeat it."Thatrsquos why Keirrsquos campaign was all about focussing the party on winning elections. Only then can we change peoplersquos lives."Welsh Labour, and First Minister Mark Drakeford will now be working closely with Keir to ensure we win the Senedd elections next year.ldquoKeir has already shown his commitment to Wales and Welsh Labour, and personally visited Cardf South and Penarth with me just a few months ago to meet local residents.ldquoWe also need to restore peoplersquos trust in the Labour Party as a force for good - a crucial part of that is tackling antisemitism."I know that Keir has the values, vision and moral compass needed to fight for justice at home and abroad ndash and that is needed more than ever.ldquoNobody could have predicted the campaign ending in these hugely dficult circumstances - and regardless of the result, our primary thoughts at the moment are with all those affected by coronavirus, and our brilliant NHS and social care staff, and key workers up and down the country who are keeping us going and saving lives every day."The Labour Partyrsquos number one priority right now is working across party lines to help the country get through this.ldquoI am also delighted Angela Rayner has been elected our new UK Deputy Leader ndash someone who I have campaigned with on a range of issues over many years. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: virus decimated marie curie hospice charity income penarth
story: End of le patients who do not want to be in hospital need to be moved to a more appropriate setting, as beds in critical care units are urgently required for patients who need lesaving treatment.The charity, which relies upon public donations and fundraising events needs to raise pound million a year to continue to run its essential frontline services across Wales.However, chief executive Matthew Reed has said the charityrsquos income has been lsquodecimatedrsquo due to the outbreak.Rachel Moses-Lloyd from Marie Curie in Wales said: ldquoWhen the NHS and public need us most, we are facing huge dficulties raising our vital funds."Along with the cancellation of hundreds of high street and supermarket collections, wersquore now losing income from the closure of our charity shops and from cancelled fundraising events."The Marie Curie Cardf and the Vale Hospice in Penarth cares for around , people each year.Its manager, Sarah Lloyd-Davies, said: ldquoAcross Marie Curie we have provided care to a few terminally ill patients who have tested positive for coronavirus or are suspected of having it and do expect this to continue in future. For reasons of patient confidentiality we are not able to discuss specic cases of care from the hospice or from the community nursing care we provide.ldquoOur hospice staff and nursing teams across Cardf and the Vale are very much on the frontline and have an important job in keeping patients out of hospital to relieve pressure on the NHS. That is important now more than ever given the coronavirus crisis. The health and wellbeing of our patients, their loved ones, and our staff is our top priority and across the hospice and community we are taking steps to protect them. This includes the use of PPE and, in-line with other providers of care, including the NHS, we have amended our visiting rules at the hospice.ldquoWith regards PPE, unfortunately, our hospice and community nursing service have been facing the same issues as the NHS in terms of getting all the equipment they need. We are screening patients with a phone call before attending their homes and staff will wear the appropriate PPE equipment during every household visit. However, we can only do this when we have the right PPE equipment available and are grateful to have recently received support from our colleagues at the Cardf and the Vale University Health Board to gain access to some PPE through their supply, for which we give our thanks.ldquoHowever we are always in need of more supplies to continue to provide vital end of le care to people living with a terminal illness, especially at this dficult time. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. pound voucher every fortnight, which equates to  school meals worth pound. for each eligible child.Councillor Lis Burnett, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Regeneration and Education, said: ldquoI have been immensely proud of the way council staff have responded to such dficult circumstances and there is no better example of that than within our Learning and Skills teams.ldquoIn title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... earlier this week following a review by the Penarth Town Council.The council previously closed the cemetery to visitors in March to tackle the spread of the coronavirus.The cemetery will be be open who remain dear to them.ldquoTo ensure that this can continue, we ask all visitors to take good care of themselves and others by observing current health guidance, including social distancing.ldquoWe must also ask that the grounds are not used for exercise or dog walking.ldquoPlease help us look after the cemetery by taking any waste materials home.ldquoPlease note that the toilets remain closed.ldquoFor health and safety reasons, it will be necessary for us to close the grounds during a funeral.ldquoIn current circumstances grounds maintenance has been scaled back and normal title: furlough extension mean workers businesses
story: ndash What will happen to workers on furlough Mr Sunak said they will continue to receive % of their pay ndash up to pound, a month ndash until the end of October.This extends the original furlough scheme to eight months since it was launched in March.The Chancellor also said there will be the possibility of part-time s for staff from August, pointing out that manufacturers have been asking for staggered shts to reopen production lines.ndash Are there more details on part-time s and can I take a job where The details will be published later this month, but Mr Sunak stressed to MPs that furloughed workers can take jobs where while on the scheme.Government advice says: ldquoIf your contract allows, you may undertake other employment while your current employer has placed you on furlough, and this will not affect the grant that they can claim under the scheme.However, staff cannot work for their employer while furloughed.ndash Will the Government continue covering the cost The Government will fund the furlough scheme, which has supported seven million jobs at a cost of pound billion a month, until the end of July.After that, companies will be expected to make a contribution to the payments, although the amount workers take home will not fall below the % mark.  The job retention scheme will be extended, for four months, until the end of October.By that point, we will have provided eight months of support to British people and businesses. Until the end of July, there will be no changes to the scheme whatsoever. pic gQznYcIrmdash Rishi SunakMay , ndash How much will businesses be expected to pay towards furlough The details will be published later this month, the Chancellor said, but it is likely to be judged on a sector-by-sector basis, similar to the details published on Monday by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategyfor companies looking to reopen under new ldquoCovid Secure measures.With certain sectors ing to some normality, others, including restaurants and gyms, remain unlikely to reopen fully for several months.ndash Can we expect to see furlough extended beyond October The Government has said it will continue to monitor the situation and is willing to adjust advice accordingly.But Mr Sunak made clear it is unlikely to be extended.He told the Commons: ldquoWe will keep everything under review but my expectation is by thenthe scheme should end. Wersquove stretched and strained to be as generous as possible to businesses and workers, which is why we have made the decision that wersquove made today.The Chancellor added: ldquoBut hellip this scheme is expensive. Itrsquos the right thing to do. The cost of not acting would have been far higher but itrsquos not something that can continue indefinitely into the future. Eight months of total support is a considerable amount of time.ndash Are there any other signicant changes to the furlough scheme More details will come this month, but MPs raised concerns from self-employed workers who pay themselves via idends, asking whether they would be able to receive further support.However, Mr Sunak insisted current support is strong enough.ndash Why is the Government announcing the extension now Under employment laws, companies must start informing any staff they plan to make redundant within  days of any changes.The previous furlough scheme was due to end by July, meaning consultations would need to begin imminently, but the extension to October will address it..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Furlough extension: What does it mean for workers and businesses  article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: coronavirus shoppers told think others more needy themselves when ordering grocery deliveries
story: Warning as NI lakes treated for algae poisonous to dogsWoman left shaken and injured after altercation with male in NI town - PSNI appeal for witnessesNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsCoronavirus: Shoppers told to think of others more needy than themselves when ordering grocery deliveriesConsumers are being urged to think of others before themselves when shopping online, amid an “unprecedented” swell in demand for food deliveries.By Adam KulaMonday, th May , : pm""Image showing a -minute wait today before shoppers can even see the delivery scheduleAodhan Connolly, spokesman for the Northern Irish wing of the British Retail Consortium, said that given the pressures on the system, deliveries should be left for only the elderly, infirm and at-risk.He also indicated that supermarkets are on something of a hiring spree right now, because of the extra manpower needed to pick customers’ baskets of groceries and deliver them.He was speaking just as the News Letter carried out a snap survey of how dferent supermarkets are catering to this spike in demand.This reporter, based in east Antrim, attempted to order groceries from five big chains which are known to deliver .Iceland did not allow this reporter to look at available delivery slots online for  minutes, because there was a queue for doing so.When it did display the delivery times, there was just one slot availablebetween noon today and Sunday, May .Sainsbury’s showed no availability for at least an entire week, ending Monday, May .Asda was unavailable until Sunday May  when some evening slots were free – but only for orders which had no alcohol.Tesco had no slots available until at least Sunday, March  .SuperValu’s nearest storecould not be reached by phone, but it is understood said they deliver only to the elderly and vulnerable, and then only in “the local community”.Mr Connollytold the News Letter: “We’ve had a growth in deliveries that’s unprecedented. We’ve seen some retailers doing delivery numbers they thought they’d be doing in eight years’ time.“But there’s a big, big thing here - there are people out there, disabled, elderly, and we’re asking the public to think before they click. Quite simply, delivery slots should be for the most vulnerable in society.”Instead the public should either get their own groceriesor get click-and-collects.The whole surge means that “here in Northern Ireland our retailers are hiring proportionately... some are permanent contracts, some are temporary”.He said they were “hiring for attitude, and training for skill” - meaning people with few qualications can still find roles in the supermarkets.He also said that “one of the laziest  narratives out there is that retailers are making a killing”. Rather, their margins have been squeezed by people buying cheaper ‘own brand’ goods instead of treating themselves.Lastly, he voiced “pride” in how day-to-day staff are handling themselves in the crisis, adding there is a “zero tolerance” approach to people shouting and becoming confrontationalasked to socially distance themselves.A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
